Hi, pc_nerd. tsMuxeR doesn't encode, it only demux's/mux's video. For AVCHD to work, hi-res movies need to have screen resolutions of 1920x1080 and 1280x720 for 1080p and 720p respectively, so that their aspect ratio is preserved. Movies with an aspect ratio of 4:3 have the correct resolution, but as you are probably aware, most theater-based movies are filmed in 2.35:1/16:9, which gives screen resolutions of around 1920x800 for 1080p (hence why you see black bars, top and bottom). This means that the cropped .m2ts/h.264 video inside most MKV containers isn't suitable without a full re-encode. We encode manually, but if you are looking for a GUI-type application that will give similar results, and also resize the video, I would recommend Dean's MultiAVCHD used in 2-pass, high-quality mode. I hope this helps.

sqlife - Your problem will be that for AVCHD to work and preserve a movie's original aspect ratio, the mattes/letterbox have to be encoded into the video file itself, giving you output resolutions of 1920x1080 and 1280x720 for 1080p and 720p respectively. Most MKV files that you download will be cropped to the aspect ratio of the movie itself, without the mattes being included, hence why you see people posting comments like, "This isn't proper 1080p!", which is incorrect, it is full 1080p, but it will not work for AVCHD.

banaducchi - we do not use a GUI type application for re-encoding, but if you are looking for one that will give similar results, MultiAVCHD used in High Quality 2-pass mode is the way to go.
